author: joshuaisbuilding
content: Inconsistency in the terminology/acronyms used in the EIPs is something I noticed when I was putting together the style guide for ethereum.org.

author: joshuaisbuilding
content:
For context, we landed on always hyphenating proof-of-* to create a hard-and-fast rule for contributors. 

Proper grammar is that proof-of-work in the middle or start of a sentence should be hyphenated: 

`Proof-of-work is a consensus mechanism`

However, if it comes at the end of a sentence or is a stand-alone title you don’t **need** to hyphenate but we agreed that this could confuse both readers and contributors, many of whom don't speak English as their native language.

author: joshuaisbuilding
content:
https://developers.google.com/tech-writing/one/words?hl=en#use_terms_consistently

This section of Google's Technical Writing course gives a well-reasoned argument for adopting this consistency (the example argues for consistency in a single article, but I think the point could extend across the entire ecosystem)
